article.title: Polarization-based Tests of Gravity with the Stochastic Gravitational-Wave Background

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates the effect of six different gravitational wave polarizations on a ring of freely-falling test particles. Which of the following statements is **incorrect**?
choices: General relativity only allows for two tensor polarizations: plus and cross.
The vector-x and vector-y modes are allowed in alternate theories of gravity.
The breathing and longitudinal modes are both scalar modes.
All six polarization modes produce a distinct, measurable response in Advanced LIGO and Virgo.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares overlap reduction functions for Hanford-Livingston (H1-L1) and Hanford-Virgo (H1-V1) baselines, representing their sensitivity to different gravitational wave polarizations.  Which statement is **correct**?
choices: H1-L1 is equally sensitive to tensor and scalar polarizations at low frequencies.
H1-V1 is less sensitive to scalar polarizations at all frequencies compared to H1-L1.
The amplitude of overlap reduction functions is directly proportional to the distance between detectors.
H1-V1 exhibits higher relative sensitivity to tensor backgrounds at high frequencies compared to H1-L1.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows Advanced LIGO's sensitivity to different gravitational wave polarizations. What conclusion can be drawn about Advanced LIGO's sensitivity?
choices: Advanced LIGO is equally sensitive to all polarizations at all spectral indices.
Advanced LIGO is most sensitive to scalar-polarized backgrounds at all spectral indices.
Advanced LIGO is more sensitive to vector and scalar backgrounds of large positive slope than to tensor backgrounds.
Existing search methods incur no sensitivity loss when detecting vector or scalar backgrounds with a purely-tensor model.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays simulated cross-correlation measurements for purely tensor and scalar stochastic backgrounds. What can be inferred from the figure?
choices: Advanced LIGO can easily distinguish between tensor and scalar polarizations at low signal-to-noise ratios.
Tensor and scalar polarizations impart a distinct shape to the cross-correlation spectra, aiding in identification.
Existing search techniques accurately identify the polarization content of weak backgrounds.
Scalar backgrounds are always louder than tensor backgrounds at the same frequency.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation 9 provides the optimal signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for detecting a stochastic gravitational-wave background. Which of the following statements about this equation is **correct**?
choices: The optimal SNR only depends on the amplitude of the background, not its polarization content.
This equation is valid only for purely tensor-polarized backgrounds.
The inner product in this equation accounts for the different sensitivities of the detector to different polarizations.
This equation is derived by assuming that the noise is non-Gaussian.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation 11 describes the scaling of the natural logarithm of the odds ratio for signal versus noise (ln OSIG\nN)  with the optimal signal-to-noise ratio (SNROPT). Which of the following statements about this equation is **correct**?
choices: ln OSIG\nN scales linearly with SNROPT.
The equation implies that weaker signals are always favored over the noise hypothesis.
The equation indicates that the strength of evidence for a signal grows rapidly with increasing SNR.
This equation assumes that the background is purely scalar-polarized.
